Variation Example: A young woman (wife) who farts easily creates embarrassing situations. A suitor observes her secretly & counts her farts. Or, she tries to cure her problem by stopping up her backside with the alarm whistle of the fire department. As she dances, the whistle plays, & the other people think a fire has broken out. In some variants, the shoemaker’s wife farts so horribly that her husband stops up her backside with tar & leather. To prevent her from bursting, he makes a small hole in the leather with his awl. This is the origin of organ pipes (wind instruments).
A young woman boasts to her suitor that she can weave very fast. While the suitor watches, she weaves so fast that she drops the shuttle.

Classifications: The Wedding That Did Not Take Place
Variation Example: On the way to the wedding the bridegroom steps into a puddle & soils the dress of his bride. Angry, she refuses to marry him. Later they try again to have the wedding, but this time the bridegroom balks. By the third time, the mayor (clergyman) refuses to officiate.

A young woman is visited by her suitor (s). Her mother brags that she can finish three portions per day. The suitor thinks (is meant to think) that this refers to her ability to spin. How-ever, he sees that the young woman is eating from several dishes at once. He does not want to have a wife with such an appetite, so he leaves.
A father-in-law disguises himself as a beggar & visits the house of his future daughter-in-law. He finds the house ill-kept, & the woman treats him badly. (He advises his son not to marry her.)

A young woman of marriageable age is blind (half blind, nearsighted). When a suitor visits her, the young woman & her mother try to trick him into overlooking the daughter’s dis-ability. The mother hides a nail somewhere (in the hay, on the floor) where the daughter can pretend to find it. Later, the daughter reveals her poor vision by mistaking the butter (coffee pot) for the cat & shooing it off the table. The suitor leaves. In some variants the suitor asks her to kiss him & presents his naked backside for the kiss.

A suitor leads his blind fiancée around her house (in the forest, through the swamp) & steals her posses-sions. Or a doctor treating the eyes of a nearly-blind woman steals all her possessions. When he leaves, she refuses to pay for her treatment. She insists that she could see better before her treatment, because then she was able to see the things in her house.

In order not to reveal their speech impediments, sisters are forbidden by their mother to speak to a suitor who has come to visit them. The daughters forget & speak, thus exposing their speech defects.

A stutterer is going to be married (is a matchmaker). As he goes to the young woman’s house, he is advised not to speak if possible. At the table, he notices that the po tatoes are about to burn (that he has no spoon). He begins to speak & reveals his stutter. The marriage is canceled.

Classifications: The Girl Who Ate So Little
Variation Example: mother boasts that her daughter eats very little. Her suitor observes the daughter as she cooks or bakes & sees that this is not true. Or, the fiancée, who claims that she eats hardly any bread, drinks extra wine.
A young wife cooks food that is always full of lumps (garbage). She explains to her husband (mother-in-law, guests) that what he found in the food is not a lump, but her child’s sock.

Classifications: The Suitor Takes Offense at a Word
Variation Example: The Suitor Takes Offense at a Word used by the girl. A suitor takes of fense at the woman wooed by him (at something she says), but then thinks better of it.

A suitor visits a poor farm. The family (the potential bride or bridegroom) desperately try to pretend that they are rich (they refer to their one cow as cattle, play other word games). The suitor discovers the truth.

A princess wants to marry whichever boy is able to jump over a haystack so big that she cannot urinate over it. The boy has sexual intercourse with her & easily performs the feat because the young woman has lost her unusual ability along with her maiden head.

Classifications: The Girl with the Ugly Name
Variation Example: A young woman is ashamed of her ugly name. Her mother gives her a prettier one. When she addresses her daughter by her new name, the daughter does not respond, so the mother has to revert to using the old name.

Classifications: The Unwilling Suitor Advised from the Tree
Variation Example: A young woman whose suitor hesitates to propose to her wants to hurry him along. She hides behind a tree and, pretending to be an angel, advises the man that he should get married. The man obeys the divine command & marries the young woman.

Three young women dip their hands in water. Whichever of them has the hands that are the first to dry will be the first to marry. The clever youngest insists that she does not want to marry, & waves her hands in the air to emphasize this. Thus her hands dry the quickest & she wins the contest.

Classifications: Foolish Bride Gives Away Her Dowry
Variation Example: A suitor & a matchmaker visit a foolish young woman whose parents are not at home. The young woman follows her mother’s advice literally & gives the visitors her dower.
A suitor comes to visit three sisters although their house has not been cleaned. The first two sisters apologize for the disorder, but the third cleans the room for him. He marries the third.
A young woman tells her suitor that she cannot cook. “That doesn’t matter”, he says, “because I have nothing to cook anyway”.
A mother seeks a suitable wife for her son. She decides on a young woman who does nothing else when she washes.

The king visits the house of a man (family mem-bers) who complains about his poverty. The king asks whether he reads the Bible regularly, & the man says yes, he is a great Bible reader. The king secretly puts some money inside the poor man’s Bible. On his next visit, it is still there.
A young woman worries about her approach-ing marriage. When her mother tries to reassure her, the daughter replies, “It was easy for you because you married father, but I have to marry a stranger”.
Misc. type with diverse variants.
A proclamation is read in church that says that it is forbidden for any young man to marry a young woman from another parish (that the men are required to marry the local old maids).

An old maid prays to God (saint) for a husband. The sexton (the wished-for husband) hides behind the altar (saint’s statue) & tells her (pretending to be God) to put her foot on her neck (to denude herself) or to do something else that puts her in an shameful situation.

An old maid prays to a statue of the Virgin Mary, asking her to grant her a husband. Hidden behind the statue, a man (sexton) answers that this cannot be. The old maid tells the baby Jesus to keep quiet, she had been speaking to his mother who will be more sympathetic to her request. In some variants a saint does not answer the prayer of a certain woman. The woman curses him or takes violent revenge on his picture (statue).

Classifications: Old Maid Married to a Devil
Variation Example: An old maid who is tired of living alone cries out in despair, “I would even marry the devil, if he would have me!” The devil comes & carries her off (marries her). Or as she lies down hoping to die. A trickster climbs into her bed & she enjoys the sensation of “sweet death”.
An old maid wants to marry regardless of who her husband is. A wolf (bear) passes by (is brought by). She takes him for her husband (and he eats her).

An old maid wants to get married. A man promises to marry her if she is able to nibble (three) nails (beans, nuts). After a while he asks her if she has nibbled the nails yet? “We can get married now”, she replies, “After the one in my mouth I’ve only two more to go”.

An old maid courts a young man. He promises to marry her if she will spend the entire night naked (lightly clothed) on the roof of the house (another place). While waiting she repeats a saying again & again, freezes to death & falls down from the roof.
A mother tells her old maid daughter to say “Tirlipp” repeatedly, to keep her lips pretty.

Classifications: Old Maid Wants to Attract Attention
Variation Example: An old maid complains that she goes to church but no man has ever taken notice of her. Her father advises her to wear a dog’s collar or a wreath of twigs around her neck. She follows this advice & reports back that everyone in church stared at her & even laughed.
A mother advises her unmarried daughter to keep her mouth half closed in front of her suitors. The daughter does so but speaks even more loudly.
Misc. type with diverse variants.

An aged philosopher (Aristotle) warns his stu-dent (Alexander the Great) against letting himself be dominated by his wife. Alexander withdraws from his wife (Phyllis, Roxane, Candacis, Campaspe). In revenge the neglected queen makes the phil-osopher fall in love with her & he pursues her with proposals.Pretending to woo him, she demands that he crawls on his hands & knees & let her ride on his back. Alexander surprises Aristotle in this undignified position. Ashamed, the philoso-pher an swers quickly that he was trying to warn Alexander against such fool ishness. Alexander forgives Aristotle & continues to follow his teachings (Aristotle is so ashamed that he has to leave the country).

A mother favors her own daughter, whom she thinks is more diligent than her daughter-in-law, although actually the reverse is true. For example she praises her daughter for spinning a big spool every week, & she criticizes her daughter-in-law for spinning only one small spool per day. She does not see that seven small spools are more than one big one.

(Vidua.) A woman mourns her dead husband by his grave (in his tomb, in a house nearby) & is completely inconsolable. Near the cemetery a soldier (knight) guards a gallows on which a man has been hanged. One cold night the soldier leaves his post & visits (spends the night with) the widow. When he returns, he finds that the corpse which he was supposed to guard has been stolen. In order to prevent him from being punished, the widow offers to have her husband’s body exhumed & substituted for the one on the gallows (the soldier proposes this). (The soldier promises to marrry her. The woman knocks her husband’s teeth out, in order to make the body like that of the stolen corpse. The soldier punishes the woman for her callousness by refusing to marry her.

A woman (widow) who wants to marry her farmhand asks the priest what he thinks of this idea. He advises her to listen to the bells. She believes they recommend the marriage. Her husband turns out to be a heavy drinker, & the wife complains to the priest. He advises her again to listen to the bells. Now these tell her not to marry the farmhand, but it is too late. In some variants, it is a young man who listens to the advice of the bells. His wife’s obstinate nature makes his life difficult. In the end he manages to subdue her.

A clergyman visits a woman whose husband has recently died. He advises her to seek consolation for her grief in the Bible. She points to her husband’s trousers hanging on the wall & says, “There are his trousers, but there is no consolation in them any more”. (Or, “No book can give consolation like what was in those trousers used to”.)
